<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 114, 606, 139]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 161, 185, 192]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 210, 163, 240]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 203, 395, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[591, 210, 688, 240]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 203, 861, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 263, 170, 279]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 286, 343, 302]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[744, 263, 861, 279]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[744, 287, 861, 302]]<|/det|> May/June 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 311, 861, 325]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 354]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 667, 381]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 218, 412]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 850, 578]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 604, 208, 618]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 620, 693, 650]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 678, 865, 802]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 97, 91, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 655, 116]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 168, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 127, 875, 159]]<|/det|>
Use the adhesive putty to attach the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass to the metre rule as close as possible to the \(80\mathrm{cm}\) mark, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 165, 823, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 280, 507, 298]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 310, 185, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 310, 737, 327]]<|/det|>
The distance between the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark and the centre of the mass is \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 339, 366, 357]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 368, 876, 386]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 69, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 69, 180, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 69, 520, 87]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 92, 792, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 365, 509, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 395, 165, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 395, 752, 414]]<|/det|>
Suspend the rule from the long string loop at the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 425, 165, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 425, 875, 459]]<|/det|>
Add the two \(50 \text{g}\) masses to the mass hanger to make a total mass \(m\) of \(110 \text{g}\). Suspend mass \(m\) from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 470, 165, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 470, 270, 488]]<|/det|>
Record \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 498, 875, 516]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ............................................................ g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 529, 165, 547]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 528, 875, 562]]<|/det|>
The distance between the string loop supporting the spring and the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 573, 875, 606]]<|/det|>
The distance between the top of the top loop of the spring and the bottom of the bottom loop of the spring is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 617, 875, 650]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the string loop supporting the spring until the rule is horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 661, 165, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 661, 415, 679]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 691, 873, 708]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 720, 875, 737]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 736, 876, 754]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 875, 101]]<|/det|>
Repeat **(b)** with different values of \(m\) until you have six sets of readings. Record \(m\), \(x\) and \(b\). Include your values from **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 107, 648, 133]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{b}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 481, 876, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 509, 138, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 508, 176, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 504, 613, 532]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{b}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 508, 876, 527]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 537, 171, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 536, 437, 556]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 536, 876, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 567, 171, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 566, 579, 586]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 758, 873, 777]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 789, 875, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 804, 876, 822]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 688, 87]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(b\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 92, 524, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{b} = Px + Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 125, 386, 144]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 155, 625, 174]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in (d)(iii), determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 170, 329, 188]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 227, 875, 246]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 259, 875, 276]]<|/det|>
<form>Q = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 274, 876, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 303, 136, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 303, 876, 336]]<|/det|>
A student repeats the experiment placing the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass closer to the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 348, 668, 367]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that \(P\) and \(Q\) are both inversely proportional to \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 377, 798, 396]]<|/det|>
For this experiment, draw a second line on the graph to show the expected results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 392, 876, 410]]<|/det|>
Label this line W. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[792, 420, 876, 439]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 98, 92, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 98, 875, 116]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how the rate of cooling of a hot liquid depends on its volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 139, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 127, 875, 160]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a cup. The diameter of the base of the cup is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 168, 539, 297]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 313, 509, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 343, 329, 359]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 370, 876, 388]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 401, 141, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 401, 717, 420]]<|/det|>
Pour boiling water into the cup until it is approximately one-third full.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 431, 693, 448]]<|/det|>
When the temperature of the water is \(75^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 460, 470, 479]]<|/det|>
Record this starting temperature \(\theta_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 490, 876, 508]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_0 =\) .................................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 520, 175, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 520, 641, 537]]<|/det|>
After two minutes, measure and record the temperature \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 548, 876, 566]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 580, 166, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 580, 336, 597]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\Delta \theta\) using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 609, 531, 628]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta \theta = (\theta_0 - \theta).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[515, 666, 876, 684]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta \theta =\) .................................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
